Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body (skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body). Lupus can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can also affect other parts of the body, including skin, joints, and internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic issues, including inflammation throughout the body.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include ulcers in the mouth and on the genitals, and skin issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). It can cause various complications, including those affecting autonomic regulation, leading to dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome – a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the HIV virus. It weakens your immune system by destroying important cells that fight disease and infection.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including issues with the nervous system and heart rhythm problems like dysautonomia.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Dysautonomias are common in these disorders.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features of several connective tissue diseases such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can include symptoms like inflammation, dysautonomia, and skin changes.

diagnoses: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (in its early stages can present with hyperthyroidism before progressing to hypothyroidism)
Chronic Immune System Disorders (e.g., Lupus, Sjögren’s Syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells accumulate in the skin and/or internal organs leading to symptoms like flushing, susceptibility to infections, and possibly basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to symptoms such as basophilia, susceptibility to infections, and difficulty finding words due to central nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the airway, face, and intestines. Flushing can also be a response to the swelling.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently high number of eosinophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood for at least six months without any identifiable cause, which can cause damage to multiple organs.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome occurring in patients with carcinoid tumors, leading to flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and increased risk of infections due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells and the release of chemicals like histamine, leading to a wide range of symptoms including flushing, susceptibility to infections, and possibly angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that affects plasma cells. Patients can have increased susceptibility to infections, and less commonly, symptoms like flushing or skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and damage to organs and tissues, including potential skin symptoms like flushing and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged. It can lead to skin changes, neuropathies that may manifest as word-finding difficulties, and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Acquired C1 Inhibitor Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition that leads to recurrent episodes of angioedema due to the deficiency of C1-inhibitor, affecting the regulation of the complement system, part of the immune system. It can sometimes be associated with autoimmune or lymphoproliferative disorders that may present with basophilia or susceptibility to infections.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.reasoning: Shares common symptoms like hyperthermia, and can exacerbate or mimic bronchitis and pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Pneumonia
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly mentioned as a symptom; can be a primary cause of hyperthermia and respiratory difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to obstructive sleep apnea and exacerbate conditions like bronchitis and pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Acute Bronchitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly mentioned; can be associated with hyperthermia and complicate lung conditions.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly mentioned; while mainly a sleep disorder, it can exacerbate respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.reasoning: Symptoms can include hyperthermia, bronchitis-like symptoms, and pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause difficulty breathing and exacerbate respiratory conditions mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.reasoning: May cause pulmonary edema, leading to pneumonia, and exacerbate obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause pneumonia, hyperthermia, and chronic bronchitis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: May cause lung granulomas mimicking pneumonia and obstructive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic hepatitis could explain abnormal liver enzymes, fibrosis, and potentially cause vaginitis due to overall body inflammation. Increased immunoglobulins could be a response to chronic infection.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition involves inflammation and fibrosis of the liver and can cause abnormal liver enzymes. The autoimmune nature of the disease could account for increased immunoglobulins. Associated fatigue could explain frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cirrhosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This is a chronic disease that leads to progressive fibrosis of the liver. It often presents with abnormal liver enzymes and can be associated with increased immunoglobulins due to the body's autoimmune response.

diagnoses.name: Non-alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH)
diagnoses.reasoning: NASH can lead to liver fibrosis and abnormal liver enzymes. Though it doesn't directly explain vaginitis or increased immunoglobulins, systemic inflammation could contribute to these findings.

diagnoses.name: Hepatic Fibrosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This is a direct match for the liver fibrosis symptom and also associates with abnormal liver enzymes. Secondary complications could potentially explain the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare disease involves inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts, leading to abnormal liver enzymes. Associated autoimmune disorders could explain increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Although primarily affecting the eyes and mouth, Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease that could mediate increased immunoglobulins and liver involvement (abnormal enzymes, fibrosis). Sleep disturbances like frequent waking are common.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE is an autoimmune condition that can affect the liver (enzymes, fibrosis), cause increased immunoglobulins, and contribute to vaginal inflammation. Sleep issues are also documented in SLE patients.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV infection can lead to increased immunoglobulins, hepatic fibrosis, and abnormal liver enzymes. Opportunistic infections may cause vaginitis, and the condition can disturb sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While not a direct cause of liver pathology, chronic fatigue syndrome could explain the frequent waking and involve immune dysregulation, potentially increased immunoglobulins. Secondary effects and comorbidities might account for liver enzyme alterations and fibrosis.

diagnoses: Bacterial Infections (e.g., Salmonella, E. coli, Campylobacter)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. Your immune system's job is to keep you healthy by fighting harmful pathogens. It does this by attacking anything it thinks could put your body in danger. This response can cause symptoms such as sneezing, hypotension, angioedema, hives, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to something you're allergic to, such as peanuts or bee stings. Anaphylaxis causes your immune system to release a flood of chemicals that can cause you to go into shock — your blood pressure drops suddenly and your airways narrow, blocking breathing. Symptoms include a rapid, weak pulse; a skin rash; and nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: A skin reaction that causes itchy welts, which can range in size from small spots to large blotches several inches in diameter. It is caused by an allergic reaction in the body. The allergic reaction can be from an unknown source or a known allergen like certain foods, medications, or insect stings.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An area of swelling of the lower layer of skin and tissue just under the skin or mucous membranes. The swelling may occur in the face, eyes, lips, tongue, larynx, abdomen, or arms and legs. Angioedema is often the result of an allergic reaction, which can be triggered by a wide range of substances or conditions.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. The rash isn't contagious or life-threatening, but it can be very uncomfortable. Many substances can cause such reactions, including soaps, cosmetics, fragrances, jewelry, and plants.

diagnoses.name: Drug allergy
diagnoses.description: Any allergic reaction to a medication. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and include hives, itching, rash, and fever. Severe reactions can lead to anaphylaxis, a life-threatening condition that requires emergency medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Even a tiny amount of the allergy-causing food can trigger signs and symptoms such as digestive problems, hives, or swollen airways. In some people, a food allergy can cause severe symptoms or even a life-threatening reaction known as anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells and inappropriate release of mast cell mediators. This can result in a wide range of chronic symptoms, including those related to allergy such as hives, swelling, low blood pressure, difficulty breathing, and severe allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the face, extremities, gastrointestinal tract, and airways. Unlike allergic angioedema, it does not typically itch and is not caused by an allergic reaction. It is caused by a deficiency or malfunction of certain proteins that help to regulate the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic urticaria
diagnoses.description: Chronic hives without a known cause. The condition is characterized by repeated episodes of hives and itching that last six weeks or longer. The exact cause of idiopathic urticaria is unknown, but it may be the result of an immune response.
An acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause angioedema, syncope due to shock, and respiratory symptoms like nasal congestion.

A genetic disorder causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). Some episodes may be associated with syncope due to sudden vascular leakage, and nasal congestion due to fluid accumulation.

A common cause of fainting (syncope), which can sometimes be associated with emotional stress and might present alongside symptoms like nasal congestion due to a concurrent upper respiratory infection or allergic reaction.

An allergic reaction to airborne particles that can cause nasal congestion, and in severe cases, might lead to syncope due to respiratory distress. Angioedema might also be present as part of the allergic reaction.
Syncope caused by various cardiac issues. In rare cases, cardiac problems can lead to swelling and congestion if there is associated heart failure.
A condition where mast cells excessively release chemical mediators, leading to symptoms such as angioedema, syncope, and nasal congestion.

A side effect of ACE inhibitor medications, which can cause life-threatening angioedema and potentially syncope. Nasal congestion is less commonly directly related but might be present due to concurrent respiratory issues.

A condition causing chronic nasal congestion without the allergic component. If associated with severe nasal blockage, it might indirectly contribute to episodes of syncope, particularly in older or vulnerable individuals.

A form of reflex syncope that can occur in response to a trigger, such as stress or pain, potentially accompanied by temporary symptoms like mild facial swelling or nasal congestion due to the stress response.
An allergic reaction to medication which can cause symptoms ranging from mild (nasal congestion, skin rash) to severe (angioedema, syncope due to anaphylaxis).

diagnoses: Anaphylactic shock due to food allergy

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura includes visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear before the headache and last for about 20 to 60 minutes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells start to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden headache, numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd have in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms, which mimic a stroke, can include headache, numbness, weakness, and abrupt difficulty with vision or speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Any growth of abnormal cells within the brain tissue. Headache associated with a brain tumor can be persistent or severe, and may be accompanied by vomiting, numbness, or weakness on one side of the body. It might also cause changes in vision.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the membranes (meninges) covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include severe headache, vomiting, high fever, stiffness in the neck, and numbness or weakness. It requires immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Brain aneurysm
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a weak spot in the brain’s arterial wall bulges and fills with blood. It can be asymptomatic but in severe cases, if it ruptures, can cause a sudden and extreme headache, nausea, vomiting, visual disturbances, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms vary widely and include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness, muscle spasms, and, in some cases, acute or chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a diseased blood vessel within the brain bursts, allowing blood to leak inside the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden and severe headache, numbness or weakness, confusion, vomiting, seizure, and difficulty with vision or speech.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive crisis
diagnoses.description: A severe increase in blood pressure that can lead to a stroke. Headache, vomiting, and numbness or weakness can be symptoms. Hypertensive crisis is a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Temporal arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the arteries in and around the scalp, causing a headache that may be associated with visual impairment, jaw pain while chewing, and scalp tenderness. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent vision loss.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain. It can cause symptoms similar to a stroke but typically lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can be cancerous or non-cancerous (benign) and can affect brain function depending on the tumor's location, size, and type. Symptoms can include headaches, weakness, problems with speech, and neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a powerful headache that often happens with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. It can last hours to days and can significantly affect your quality of life. Some people may experience aura before the actual headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, typically from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including headache, weakness, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The cause can be an infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and fatigue. It can lead to severe complications such as memory problems, hearing loss, or epilepsy.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by viruses, bacteria, or other microorganisms. Symptoms include severe headache, fever, and stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. It causes loss of muscle control. ALS is a progressive disease, meaning it gets worse over time.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA)
diagnoses.description: Primary progressive aphasia is a type of neurological syndrome in which language capabilities become progressively impaired. It usually begins with word-finding difficulties and progresses to a near-total inability to speak, while other cognitive functions remain relatively preserved.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and electric shock sensations that occur with certain neck movements.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms of stroke include sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body; confusion; trouble speaking or understanding speech; and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack in its symptoms resembles a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Common symptoms include sudden weakness, numbness or paralysis in your face, arm or leg, especially on one side of your body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: Diabetic neuropathy is a type of nerve damage that can occur if you have diabetes. High blood sugar (glucose) can injure nerves throughout your body. Diabetic neuropathy most often damages nerves in your legs and feet. Symptoms can range from pain and numbness in your legs and feet to problems with your digestive system, urinary tract, blood vessels, and heart.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Brain tumors can develop directly on the brain (primary brain tumors), or cancer can begin in other parts of your body and spread to your brain as secondary (metastatic) brain tumors. Symptoms of brain tumors can include headaches, often worse in the morning; nausea; speech or vision problems; and weakness or numbness in parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.details: Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurologic and psychiatric symptoms. Because B12 is crucial for the maintenance of the myelin sheath surrounding nerves, a deficiency can cause numbness, weakness, and problems with mobility.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. The first symptom is usually a red rash, which may look like a bull's eye. But it can also cause flu-like symptoms, including fever, tiredness, headaches, and muscle or joint pain, as well as neurological problems like weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.details: In diabetes, elevated blood sugar levels can lead to a variety of complications, including nerve damage (diabetic neuropathy) that can cause weakness and numbness typically in the hands and feet, but it may also cause problems in other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble speaking, and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. It’s often characterized by sudden speech difficulties, paralysis, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A brain tumor can cause headaches that don’t go away and can become more severe. Other symptoms can include seizures, personality or memory changes, nausea, fatigue, and numbness or weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: Hypothyroidism, your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. This can lead to a variety of symptoms, such as fatigue, weight gain, feeling cold, and can also cause weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause fatigue, weakness, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Often, symptoms include headaches and numbness in various parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.details: Anxiety disorders can cause physical symptoms such as headaches, muscle weakness, and numbness or tingling sensations in the hands and feet, often due to hyperventilation during panic attacks.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Drug Reactions (e.g., Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS])
Epilepsy (for seizures, if unconnected to inflammatory diseases)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune disorders with CNS involvement)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Autoimmune Thrombocytopenia)
